Permissive planning regimes would make it easier to build renewable and shale gas extraction schemes, but only where the local community buys into it. It would be in return for subsidised energy in that community or a share of the revenues. https://t.co/Z0Gp0hZ38U

The Government's strategy out today improves medium term security and cost of energy; this report addresses how to get bills down this winter - plenty of ideas for government to pick up as it finalises its strategy.

https://t.co/2nH83mAMwm
⚡️Incentivising investment: stronger incentives to encourage investment in fuel efficient capital equipment and changes to timing of grants to pay ahead of factory summer shutdowns
💷Speeding up existing measures: bring forward the existing plan to move to ‘half hourly pricing’, empowering consumers to use electricity when it is cheaper

🏗Supply side: a new permissive, planning regime for all renewable and any shale gas extraction schemes where a majority of residents, on a local referendum are willing to support them in return for free/subsidised energy or a share of revenues
🗯Demand side: stronger public messaging on the advantage of smart meters and pressure on energy companies to bring forward smart tariffs

📝Improved guidance: Better access to existing education/incentive schemes designed to inform consumers about energy efficiency opportunities like reducing pressure to hot water taps & reducing radiator setting on gas boilers to between 55 and 65 degrees to optimise energy output

⚡️How can government support consumers and businesses to reduce their energy bills over the short term? ⚡️

The 1922 Backbench Committee on BEIS report is full of practical ideas for what government can do to help in the short term.

https://t.co/2nH83mAMwm
